reviewText: An EXTREMELY over complicated 4X game based around ancient mythology, history, and H.P. Lovecraft. You start out the game by choosing a map, age, empire, and then making a god. The game consists of three playable ages that show the development of the playable empires. The early ages have Magical and Nonhuman factions in abundance, while the human factions of the time are just discovering bronze Copper and Bronze. This age also has the greatest amount of Magic, but also the least organised casters. The second age is marked with Human factions beggining to subjigate the assorted nonhumans with weapons of Iron and Steel augmented by enchantment. This age has a moderate balance of Magic and Organised casters. The Third age is a time were Man has all but destroyed the magical wonders of past ages. Magic is nearly drained from the world, but well organised wizards make do with what is left. After you choose your age, you choose your empire, Then make your God. Your God making sets how you will spend the next several hours of your life in this game. You select an available Deity for your faction, then get to choosing how strong it is in magic and what bonuses you get in lands were you are believed in. Say you're faction has very good yet expensive troops, yet poor magical researchers and practitioners so you can't get any late game spells, you would make your god have a dominion that boosts production and can cast what you need to be cast. FINALLY you are in the game after setting a few end game goals and options, and the real complicated hell begins. I think im going to stop soon so I am going to make this as simple as possible to summarise what you do in the actual game. Your first play through will just be throwing bodies at other bodies till you win or lose. Though what makes the game fun is the magic. One magician with some magical items and gems can single handedly destroy a quarter of an army, but what makes it complicated is knowing the exact stats of those items, spells, and how much your caster can take before fainting. I think this is way to long already and if anybody reads this far then I'm sorry if this was a mess. If you want to take the time to learn about this game and such then by all means get it.

reviewText:
This isn't a game for everyone.
The strategy game players already have their traits, but this game requires them to utilize their traits to the maximum.

Dominions 4 has so many different aspects, it'll probably take you a couple of new games to get adapted to the controls and different things you can do.
There is a huge amount of different startup settings you can use, and a huge amount of factions to choose from. Every faction is different - and I mean different not just cosmetically, but to the very essence. To give an example to show the contrast between the factions:

Late Age Agartha is a nation of cave-dwellers. Their version of cavalry rides cave drakes, their mages are skilled in earth and death magic. They also recieve a bonus to alchemy. Their best soldiers require a large amount of resources to produce. Since most of their soldiers have darkvision or are already blind, they don't get harmed from spells like Solar Eclipse and Darkness.

Late Age Lemuria is a land of the Undead (it's basically a fantasy counterpart of Ancient Rome which gets corrupted). The extent of your pretender god's dominion will always kill off the populace in provinces. You then use these dead bodies to bolster your army with spectral centurions, velites, and consuls  - not through training, but through summoning with spells. Thus, you have little use for gold or resources.
---
There are also many Pretender Gods to choose from. From a mere sculpture that has gained power through millenia of worship, to a divine burning glyph, from a titan of the sea, to a dragon. You can further customize your pretender by changing the effects of its dominion (the extent of its power), and its capabilities in magic.

Units differ wildly. Some are only recruitable in some regions, most are only available to a single nation. They have tons of attributes, a stat sheet, and commander/spellcaster/scout/priest units have an inventory for items.

The graphics are a bit of a shame, it's true. Most of the time, you won't even watch the battle replays, the random map generator creates ugly looking maps. However, the userbase (and potentially you will too), have created some lovely looking maps, worthy of Tolkien himself.

The gameplay is very complex. I don't like Let's Play videos, so I had to learn by myself. You'll need a bit of patience, some intuition, and curiosity to understand fully how it works.

But here's why this game is really worth playing: The storytelling.
The richness of the world and its backstory will pull you in. Every single unit type has a story. Every hero" type character has the potential to be your favourite character in the game.
You will spend astral magic gems

reviewText:
The first time I played after the tutorial was a singleplayer game, to get a feel for the games' mechanics. I played as R'lyeh (named for the city in which Cthulhu lies in deathless dreams) and zerg rushed everything unfortunate enough to be underwater. Then I turned my attention to the land. This is difficult as R'lyeh, as most units available to it can only survive underwater or with costly magic to allow them to breathe air or transport them in a bubble of water, and my enemies had fortified the coast at this point. So instead of raiding their ports the traditional way I summoned a bunch of sea trolls, which can survive both on land and underwater, and had them repeatedly throw themselves into suicide missions along a coastal region until the area was strewn with corpses. Then I marched the Eater of the Dead, a massive undead horror summoned from a nether realm that feeds on corpses to grow in power until it inevitably becomes too powerful for its summoner to control and breaks free, wreaking havoc indiscriminately, over to the battlefield and had it gorge itself. It broke free quickly and began rampaging, but this was all according to plan- I cast a spell to freeze the oceans over, so it could not get back down to my oceanic empire, yet was free to destroy all unfortunate enough to live above sea level. Sadly, I did not comprehend the importance of proselatyzing, so belief in me gradually ran out throughout the empire, until I had no divine dominion left and lost anyway.

Since then I have played as the lavamen of Abysia and created a second sun so there was eternal burning day, crippling the offencive of my cold-loving Niefelheim foes; As the Ashen Empire of Ermor, an undead post-apocalyptic Roman empire that spreads like an infection, turning the world into skeletons, and did the opposite, blotting out the sun and causing the entire world to age at an incredible rate (skeletons have great longevity, humans not so much); As Kailasa, an Indian-themed realm of reincarnating monkey gurus, I used the power of the stars to transform a demigod of mercy into a ruthless and indiscriminate killing machine, flying around the world with a shapeshifting dragon princess she once saved in tow and bringing destruction upon my enemies; As the amphibious subterranean civilisation of Agartha I broke an ancient seal, releasing mad gods upon the world; And so on- These are only the more prominent examples, stories many players are likely to experience because they align with each nation's strengths and lore.

Make no mistake, Dominions is only superficially yet another army-management turn-based wargame. In fact it is more of a game about great magical beings at war with each other, and the havoc they wreak in their strife for supremacy. Like certain other absurdly complex modern CRPGs with minimalistic graphics (the most prominent being Dwarf Fortress), Dominions has decent gameplay, but its real strength is in its equally complex and convoluted lore and the intriguing stories that come from it.

One of my favourite games, strongly recommend.

reviewText:
Dominions 4 is the grand champion of 4x strategy games. It might even be the king of fantasy strategy games.

Dominions 4 has incredibly deep mechanics that will, truthfuly, be quite frustrating at times but are also incredibly rewarding. This is a game where you invest alot of time into to fully understand. Every time you play you figure out a new strategy or mechanics you didnt know about. At the time of writing this review I have 274 hours into this game and I'm still learning. You can put a hundred hours into one nation and still not unlock its full potential. If you arn't willing to put time into this game you will only leave frustrated. Luckily there is a very active and incredibly helpful community over at Desura.com.

Playing this game you will raise vast armies filled with simple human warriors, incredibly strong giants, magic demi gods, demons, angels, half fish men, dragons and many more creatures. You'll have armies of hundreds of units battling eachother as mages set the battlefield afire and call upon divine lightning to destroy their foes while corrupt priests cast unholy rituals by spilling virgin blood. You'll have a unstoppable army conquering and pillaging your enemies lands but then your opponent summons a powerful hero, hundreds of years old, from ancients crypts in his home city. This hero will fight your unstoppable army. One man, versus hundreds. And he'll win. You'll have a crippled commander who can barely move. Old in his age and speaking in croaks and whispers. but all your men respect him because he is a master tacticitan, he has never been defeated in battle. Guarded by your most trusted men he commands huge armies and crushes enemy forces with ease.

The modding is where this game truly shines. Their are hundreds of mods available that change every aspect you could possibly imagine. From mods that balance to mods that are simply for fun, there is dozens of mods for every kind of player. If you're feeling brave you can mod yourself, all you need is a text and image editing program, with a official modding manual available at Illwinter's website. You can create any nation or creature you can think of. Want to play as a nation of cannabilistic, necromatic hobbit warrior society, go ahead, easily done. create as many and whatever spells you want. This game is your playground.

The setting isnt simply your standard high fantasy theme but taken from legends and myths from around the world and throughout history. You're not playing a premade fantasy world, you're creating the world. You write your heroes stories, your own nations history. You are creating the world as you play.

11/10

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun both singleplayer and multiplayer.

Single-player: Challenging and fun cause the AI is better than players at picking its battles and growing and massing hordes of units. Good to learn to play and/or you can just play this way the whole time. The game is pretty moddable but there's already so much content to learn about that personal mods are something that is enticing almost exclusively to singleplayer.

Multiplayer: Players adopt and try out crazy strategies usually that are always unique to their nation and there're thousands of overal strategies. Players make more intelligent use of spellcasting, item combinations, and formation tactics. Players also screw up entire game strategies, formation tactics, item combinations, and attacking neutral provinces they can't defeat, making player games radically more random than those against the AI.

If you have a friend who you can play with, you should absolutely try multiplayer, all the same while, if you're playing by yourself, you can take all the time in the world to do whatever you want with your micromanagement and role-play to your heart's content.

So, I decided to play as my current favourite, EA (Early Age) Ermor again.
Large random map with 9 AI's at Easy (I'm a real noob).
It goes pretty well, so I decide to jerk around and upgrade a few of my mages to insane levels.
First one gets Horror Marked (think hunted by monsters from HP Lovecrafts works) and gets murdered by a Lesser Horror. My wizard had 7 in Fire, Astral, Nature, Earth and Water.
And that wasn't even that powerful of one.
During this time, I started getting harassed by enemy spellcasters, so I put up a Dome of Flaming Death. Yes, that's the exact name of the spell.
So, when I decided to go and get my powered-up Augur Elder there, I cast Gateway.
What I didn't know was that when a Dome spell says enemy spellcasters, it means all spellcasters that either target this province or cast out of this province. Including my own.
So, now my other powerful spellcaster is toast (pun intended), this time however, I was hoist by my own petard.

10/10 would get hoist by own petard again.

reviewText:
In essence Dominions 4 is a very enjoyable strategy game that offers a very unique concept and experience. I thoroughly recommend this game for those who enjoy turn based strategy games, and D&D players.

The game features well researched historical nations fighting alongisde their own mythologies, such as Japanese Ashigaru being supported by Tengu, or Viking raiders paired with dragons. These nations are led by your own custom god who radically changes the territory that he/she/it controls, wether by making it into a fertile and well ordered land or turning it into a disease ridden, unproductive region of unrest. Or your god can simply be a towering behemoth that smashes its opponents to pieces in battle. Both methods are completly viable. The final component is the deep magic system, with apocalyptically powerful spells and summonable creatures divided into different schools. Some nations have excellent soldiers but terrible mages, and vice versa. It is very rewarding to create your own deadly combinations of different nations, gods and magics; the amount of combinations is staggering. The game is still updated fairly often bringing more nations to the increasingly large roster. Furthermore, there are many mods to keep adding content to the game.

However, the game can be rather intimidating with a frankly inadequate tutorial, making a read of the manual essential. I had to lose several games before even starting to understand what was going on, and I'm still pretty bad at it. The graphics are certainly functional but they are not exactly good either. In singleplayer there really is no diplomacy to speak of, you are constantly at war with the other players - I think that the lack of diplomacy is the biggest issue the game has.

Ultimately, Dominions 4 is a great game that I greatly enjoy playing.

One of the best strategy games I've played so far. Sure, the game interface is kinda old-school and could be a bit more intuitive. The graphics may also seem a bit odd ad first. The learning curve is therefore a bit slow and you will need a good while until you can play really effectively, but even while you have to learn, the game is much fun. And the best thing is that this game is still regularly being updated, with new units, nations and gods to play as. Absolute recommendation for all who like to invest tons of hours into their favorite strategy game.

reviewText:
When it comes to fantasy strategy games this is it, the best one of them all.

Well its got unimaginable depth and complexity, which will take you weeks, months, even years to get to the bottom of, but as many good games are, really simple to play. Good to play single player and awesome to play multiplayer, with healthy viberant mutiplayer communitys.

Want to create a completely dead world with only legions of undead in it, in Dominions 4 you can, seriously you could kill every living being in the world. Massively moddable, create your own complete nations.  Lots of player created mods and maps to try out.

If you are a fan of fantasy strategy games you need to own and play Dominions 4, worth every penny.

reviewText:
I was told I do too many negative reviews.
So I decided that all of the games I own Dominons 4 is the most deserving of reccomendation.

Dominions 4 is a game made by two devs who have worked on every iteration of Dominions.
Unlike many games which release and then charge you for additional content Dominions 4 recieves patches for new nations and units, FOR ABSOLUTELY FREE.


-------------GAMEPLAY-------------------
The gameplay is a turned based military management, strategy and tactic based game.

You have a Pretender God, the choices available depend on your nation.
Your pretender God is basically a demi-god who is trying to become the only God for the world as the big G that came before dissapeared.

You can then modify your Pretender God with magic scales which is representative of the gods magical skill. These scales also determine bless amounts which are bonuses given to holy units, which each nation has.

There is also Dominion which given it shares the name with the game is one of the most important aspects. Dominion is the Pretender God's influence, without it your God will die and you will be subjected to other Gods dominion which brings a morale detriment for you and a postive boost for morale for your enemies.

You can take negative dominions traits like chaos or death or positive ones like magic or growth. Depending on the nation some will be postive for some while harmful to others, for example MA Ulm benefits from drain and Ermor benefits from Death.

Winning conditions can be point based, deathmatch or my favorite Thrones of Ascension which are thrones of varying power that have an effect on provinces, dominion and gems.

Magic is fueld by Gems and much be researched to be usable.
Some spells require no gems but only effect Fatigue while others do. There are spells which have in battle effect and spells which can be used on the map to summon units, or attack provinces.

----------------Setting----------------------
The setting of Dominions 4 is amazing, each Nation changes based on the age its in.
Some dissapear other change dramatically.
Xibalba goes from a nation of Bat people to a nation of Frog people who enslave the Bat people.
Rlyeh goes from a nation of mindfrying fish called Aboleths into Squid people loosely based on Lovercraft who summon horrors from beyond to use as BLESSED units.

Some nations like R'lyeh that I mentioned are sea based as they start in ocean provinces and all units are able to breathe underwater.

Nations have diffrent spells which all come with their own flavor text describing the spell and its origins and value to the people who cast it.

----------------Music & Sound-----------------
Do not expect an epic soundtrack, one song and one song only, that goes on forever.
Sounds are good not great but indicate what is going on and are quite good when using iron blizzard in masse and hearing enemy splat noises.

-------------------Maps------------------------
The game comes packaged with quite a few high quality maps, there is also the ability to make random maps however they don't look the greatest.

However the game does have a very simplified map creation tool, and quite a few maps have been made for DOM 4 or converted from Dom 3.

One of my favorite maps is called Valanis and is quite beautiful visually and mechanically.

----------------------Performance----------------------
The performance is sex.
On a crappy lenova laptop which I use for work mainly is able to run the game and with most graphical options turned off can simulate very large battles which is impressive seeing as my laptop lacks a seperate video card.

My rig at home is a monster but even with a toaster with mild specs the game will run wonderfully.
One of the best aspects of the game as I enjoy being able to take my work laptop up with me on trips and being able to play the game without lugging my Tower around with me.


I highly recommend Dominions 4 for anyone looking for a great Tactics and Strategy game with a fantasy flair.

reviewText:
If it wasn't clear by my number of hours played, I love this game and I highly recommend it. If you can get past a confusing UI and sprite graphics, you'll find a wonderfully complicated and strategic game that is also filled to the brim with competing mythologies in pursuit to rule over a world.

A world that will likely be destroyed by the time you get there because you won by sacrificing thousands of virgins to summon horrors from beyond the veil to consume friend and foe alike!

And that's just one of many viable strategies to win! You can also create massive communions of mages that use its weaker members' energy as fuel to power the rest into throwing out massive firestorms upon the enemy's heads. Or you can air-drop hundreds of magical elves riding ponies into every enemy province at the same time. Or even have your pretender god wish himself physical and magical mastery until no being in existance can stand up to the sheer power.

This is, through and through, a multiplayer game. Although there is single player which can be useful for trying out certain things, the focus is on playing the game with others. Communities for Dominions 4 multiplayer can be found on Desura's Dominions 4 forum, on dom4mods, and on Something Awful. I'm sure there are other communities as well. The only thing better than plunging the world into eternal darkness so your legions of undead can rule over the living, is having ten other human players scream in horror as their people are converted into the undead masses!

reviewText:
This reminds me a lot if Master of Magic was a really complicated board game. This will run on almost any machine and the play by email multiplayer works really well for people with spotty internet connections.

You start every game by picking a nation that decides the type of mages and troops you can recruit, and then you choose and customize a god to lead your nation. I beleve there are over a hundred gods to choose from, including (but not limited to) Greek, Norse, Celtic, German, Sumerian, Chinese, Japanese, Indian and even Cthulhu-esque. There's everything from an erstaz Athena to a disembodied head with crab claws coming out of its forhead.

While the myriad of rules can seem intimidating, most people should be able to jump in and play against the computer without too much difficulty. Once you get a feel for the rules there are a few communities that regularly run blitz matches so you aren't stuck committing months of your time to a long PBEM.

reviewText:
A wonderful game. Epic (Battles with a thousand units vs a God. One Survivor), deep, intelligent and growing (new races are still being released in every age). If you're browsing then know it is well worth the price even full price. I've played it twice as long as Skyrim... longer than most of my games library added together. And each game I've played has been different:
I lead a race of aquatic mind-lords, deep in the ocean. My pretender to the throne of godhood a great Polypal Queen, giving birth to a host of magical beings that swarm the enemy with their writhing tentacles. My massive ancient mind-lords enslave the enemy with a look, curse entire armies and form communions to enhance their power to incredible levels - enslaving entire battlefields and shredding the souls of the enemy.
I've led a race of winged humanoids that live high in the mountains crafting weapons and armour from magical ice. Summoning back splendid beings from the astral spheres, 'adorable ones' beautiful to behold, too awesome for living men to dare strike.
I've seen the temptation of power topple empires. Mages suffering the ravages of old age turn to healers and eventually to death magic to be reborn as wight mages, drawing on the power of conquered lizard shaman to blot out the sun and cover the battlefield with a never ending horde of undead warriors. Then in a latter age casting spells that change the entire globe, covering the lands in darkness and advancing the slow decay of time till all is withered and dead.
I've felt the fear of a horror-mark. A towering giant of a God, multi-armed and terrifying touched by the unspeakable powers. The last act of a doomed race to mark it, a slow, pyrrhic victory. My God, with power beyond reckoning destined to be stalked forever by the creatures that lurk beyond the veil. Each touch from the terrifying apparitions further marking the Great God for the attention of the astral beings until at last... a doom horror, Each name more frightening than the last. The Eater of Gods arrives to feast. My God is no more...

A brilliant game. I could say more, it's worthy of praise. More than a little tough to get into (you'll make lots of mistakes and you need to practice in SP before trying your hand at MP), dated graphically (2D spites, only one artist working on the game) and a little micromanagement heavy (Ok very micromanagement heavy. You can script every mage, every squad, equip every commander and forge every magical item... lots to consider, lots to weigh up and lots of stats if you're into that). But, if none of that puts you off and the thought of summoning hordes of undead, demons, shrimp or cross-bred monstrosities appeals:

Buy it.
Or stick it on your wish-list and get it when you can afford it.
Play a few games.
Get your friends to all play on a big map with diplomacy, backstabbing and roleplaying. Keep an eye on the little guy, he's probably planning a surgical strike with teleporting golems, gathering blood-slaves to taint the magic of the world to cause all magic but blood to bring the attention of the horrors. Or he may just have had lots of misfortune and be fighting against barbarians, vampires, roaming bands of heroes, blights and plagues and extreme weather. (Could be luck... or it could be that somone doesn't like him very much).

I hope you get it, I'm glad I did.

reviewText:
Perhaps the number of hours I’ve been playing deceives you? Hmm? Well, let me put it bluntly. This game is pretty awesome. It is a strategy game at its core. And in the purest sense, a classical war game involving fantastical creatures and beasts. I refer to it as a war game due to the nature of game play. It is hard-core and classical in that, there is no diplomacy. Pure tactics and strategy is needed to succeed. You make your own diplomacy and essentially create your own story.

A word of warning, this game is far better when played online or with other people. Don't get me wrong. There is a single player aspect but in my personal opinion. The single player aspect against the AI is probably best used as a way of testing your builds, possible tactics and army composition. Yes, there is a very in depth combat system in the game, very much akin to Total war. For better or for worse, you have no control over these clashes (represented by crude graphics combating it out, looks pretty appealing in my opinion), and instead you can script what your troops would do. This makes for a more intense session and allows you to experiment possible tactics. By making battles less hands on (like total war), it enables you to feel more like a proper general :) Each unit has a hand drawn sprite and there are over a dozen nations to pick from (from a selection of three ages). Then there is the pretender creation. That is the best part of the game. To create a pretender ‘god’ that represents you. The number of possibilities that come to creating a god is endless.  You can make a combat oriented super god, or perhaps a more spell oriented support god. Maybe even an immobile stone god that confers perks to your troops. The choice is yours!
I admire the game. Not just because it is a pure grounded classical war game involving fantasy creatures, gods and what not, but more-so due to the amount of detail put into the game. That is a feat that no game can accomplish (well at least with higher graphics anyway).

Perks
-Really in depth combat system with a multitude of troop types and nations to pick from.
-Formation system
-Pretender Creation
-Randomised map generation
-Excellent multiplayer game
-Mod capabilities

Cons
-Graphics can be a major turn off for a lot of players (especially those who look to graphics as the main factor for enjoying a game)
-Though battles are very detailed (modelling each individual soldiers move and attack), they are very heavily scripted and despite it following orders. There can be tendencies where some of your units won’t follow orders properly (I understand orders cannot be followed to a point but in some cases, it can be pretty extreme).

So to conclude, my highlight of the game would have to be the combat mechanics and the pretender system. Some people may dislike not having direct control over battles, but I personally think it makes for a far more strategic game. Not to mention, back in the day, generals would not be able to control their infantry or cavalry directly anyway. Even now, there is a margin of error when it comes to following orders from a higher up. I think that is very well simulated in this game. By letting players script orders, you are almost planning your move from a war room. Not knowing exactly what is going to happen. That is how it should be done :D

reviewText:
Enjoyed Master of Magic but find that 4x games these days just don't go deep enough for you?

Dominions takes that, strips away the civilization citybuilding aspect, and just goes for a full-on fantasy wargame.  Mages, spells, monsters, commanders, magic items... reviewText: If you're looking for a turn-based multiplayer game which you can play regardless of timezones, in which you actually do significant stuff every turn, which has lots of depth, and loads instantly (but in which you may spend an hour or more deciding what to do in particularly competitive games), Dominions 4 may be worth a look.\n\nIt supports play-by-email, and games are usually run through www.llamaserver.net, which handles setting up games, accepting pretender submissions, hosting the turns and sending out the new turn files, receiving your .2h orders files and having a page which shows who has submitted their turn and who hasn't... reviewText: Great game once you get the basics of it. It's a bit like Dota or LoL where you have to know pretty much everything about the game to actually win. If you have a gift card then I definately recommend getting this, otherwise, wait until the price goes down (as $35 is a hefty price tag for this game) and hopefully when that happens, the game will be better balanced and patched up.

reviewText:
This is a deep fantasy TBS game with a relatively steep learning curve.  It is well worth the effort to learn.  If you enjoy this sort of game and have not played previous Dominions games, I *strongly* recommend it.  This is true even considering the high price tag for what is essentially a niche indie game.  You will enjoy a unique and well-crafted strategy game.  It is well worth it!

However, I am personally disappointed that it is only a small upgrade from Dominions 3.  The interface is much better and everything is cleaner.  But gameplay-wise, it is virtually identical with only a few new features.  This is a shame because - while the game is indeed quite well designed - it does have areas that could have been improved or redesigned.  For instance, the spell research system could be done better, the spell circles could feel less generic, and there is certainly room for more spells and more interesting spells.  Likewise, although Prentender customization (A Prentender is your nation's god who is vying to become the one true god) is one of the most fun parts of the game, an even deeper system would be appreciated.  Yet it is essentially unchanged from Dominions 3.  Furthermore, I would have loved to see even basic diplomacy and trading introduced to the series.  As it stands, there is only war between you and the other nations unless they are on your team from the start.  Additionally, while graphics are not important in this sort of game, it is still disappointing that they are mostly unchanged from Dominions 3.  There are some higher-res sprites and the 3D ground combat textures are slightly higher resolution, but it really looks pretty much the same.  Sadly, there are still no overworld spell visual effects; Dominions should take a page from Master of Magic.  Even basic overworld spell effects would make spellcasting much more satisfying!  Overall, I felt as though there were many missed opportunities for improvement.  I felt like I was playing Dominions 3.5, not Dominions 4.

So if you own Dominions 3, is it worth the price tag?  Well, if you play a lot and want a better interface with a few new features, then yes.  Just don't expect much of a change in actual gameplay.  I just hope these talented developers can provide a more substantial update in the next iteration of this wonderful series.

reviewText:
If Civilisation 5 is wide as an ocean, and deep as a puddle. Then Dominions 4 is the exact opposite. The map might look simple. The graphics might make this game seem outdated but the sprites are just the skin to an enormous gameplay framework.

God is dead, and the pretender gods of the world are waging war to determine who is going to be the undisputed god of the realm. You, the player, will customize a pretender god to fight for dominance. The key selling point here is that there is so much diversity to the pretender gods. You can make a vampire lord, a dragon, a immovable monolith (like deadspace) and even Zeus himself if you wanted to.

I suggest picking this game up if you are interested in a good MULTIPLAYER wargame experience. The game works wonderfully with play by email" and even frantic games like myself who always put the gamespeed to max can enjoy the slower pace of PBEM because battles can determine EVERYTHING much like an roguelike.

The game comes with a huge manual

reviewText: The 4th iteration of the Dominions series, it remains, as ever, a game for the hardcore multiplayer strategist. It is fantasy wargaming at its finest. Turn-based on the WE-GO system, in multiplayer this game will test your tactical and strategical skills as few others do, while juggling logistics based on an economy of ten to twelve primary resources, depending on how you count them. A plentitude of maps exist for the game and are available via mod-sites and, for those preferring randomness, it ships with a random map generator.\n\nSadly, the game is considerably better for multiplayer than singleplayer, as the AI is incapable of providing a challenge to any competent player: there are simply too many potential options to deal with in terms of magic; That said, a new player should expect dozens of hours of play before reaching a level where the AI can consistently be beaten on the highest difficulty setting and there's a live and vibrant multiplayer community for the game.

First and foremost, while I heartily recommend this game, I must underline that this game is NOT for everyone.

First impressions for most people are horrible: the graphics are dated, the audio gets irritating after a short while and the user interface is one of the worst I've ever had to deal with - although there are few very welcome improvements over Dominions 3. reviewText:
I've got 108 listed hours on this game but that's only because I've got a folder for batch SP/MP starts for practice.  I play the hell out of this game and it's still unbelievably challenging (especially in multiplayer) and interesting.  There are still nations that I haven't even played, much less effectively.

What I will say is that it's not as fresh as it was.  I've begun to find it tedious practicing expansion, and I only do it when I feel inspired.  It's definitely worth it but it doesn't look like it to a lot of people, and it's not a perfect game - it's just deep and complex and grand.  I have friends who don't like the lack of control in battle, particularly since the AI can sometimes leave a lot to be desired.But even as a relatively casual player these days I can still recommend this game one hundred percent.

The various multiplayer and modding communities (Desura, dom3mods, etc.) make this game for me.  New content and support and guides help get both new players and veterans out of the gate to start experiencing the game - which is where you really start to develop an understanding of the nuance.

My suggestion to you is to buy it when it's on sale, and play it with your friends (who did the same).  Great way to play with and against humans before stumbling into a major community where you will lose often - in a game that usually has 8-20 players, a 15-20% win rate is pretty high.

Go have Dagon lead lovecraftian shamblers out of the ocean to crush the egyptian lizardmen who are flanked by Jotun frost giants and dinosaur-riding amazons.  It's pretty cool.

reviewText:
A low graphic, yet good strategy game, following the motif of Master of Magic. Basically you choose a 'nation' to control, build a wanna-be-god for them and set to strategy against other nations where new gods are rising as the old overgod is ... gone. You can equip your leaders/special units with mystical items and there is lots of overland spells and ordinary ones. Not all countries rely on magic. Very diverse game with good replayability factor.

Music score is a little unusual medevil reporductions, though not bad at all. Wish there were a little bit more music themes.

Developer is quite often patching and rebalancing the game, adding more things. Nations, summonable creatures and such at his own pace, but regularely and probably like with his earlier games on a constant basis for years. Pace is slow, but constant. Game is stable, updates are just extra bonus in general.

reviewText: While not the prettiest game to ever grace a monitor, there is so much content here it's hard to not recommend if you like deep, complex strategy games. The learning curve is somewhat steep, but if you don't mind watching a few basic tutorials and/or gameplay videos, and doing a bit of research, you'll be in for a ride with Dominions 4. I'm actually a bit sad I've rediscovered this game after initially being overwhelmed, as I see it devouring my free time in the near future. Few games can boast having such a wealth of options, tactics, maps, and units, and the AI seems happy to pile armies on you and make things interesting if not difficult. Throw in multiplayer, which I've yet to try, and you have a huge heap of game here. Highly recommended, can't wait to get back to it.

reviewText:
An incredibly deep turn-based strategy game with fascinating and deligtfully detailed game lore. A very steep early learning curve that once surmounted gives way to hundreds of hours of gameplay. Most intriguing and complicated magic system that I've ever seen in a strategy game.

As for cons, there are many. Single player AI is remarkably useless creation that in battle contends itself with throwing completely random selections troop at you, with no ability to plan strategies or conduct diplomacy. Make no mistake, Dominons 4 is a multiplayer game to the bone, and much of it's lasting appeal is directly in proportion to how much you enjoy scheming and devicing strategies for beating human players.

The multiplayer system itself is frankly archaic, requiring the hosting of an old-fashioned game server for other players to connect to and upload their turns to specific games. Individual matches might run for months at a time.

The magic system while complex, is daunting to master and requires memorization of the vast spell lists to properly use. There are numerous exploitable mechanics that are slow to get fixed, as well as a plethora of bugs.

Despite all it's flaws, Dominions 4 is still a true gem for turn-based strategy fans. It's quite unpolished and with decidedly indie production values, but with deep and rewarding mechanics.

reviewText: If you want graphics, GTFO. If you want a great game without caring about graphics, welcome. Dominions 4 is one of the best experiences for those who enjoy strategy games. There are a crapton of nations to choose to conquer the world, each with customizeable features such as the growth of your dominion (basically who follows your god) or the heat or cold of your lands. The way you win is up to you, you choose how to win.  In my experience, it is THE most customizeable turn-based strategy I have ever seen. You position your units in your armies, and decide if they will either be in box formation, a long line, and who and how they will attack. You decide how many units go into this army, and who goes into that one. Maybe you want to go in, hacking and slashing with swords and axes. OR, you can defend your mges with your units, and control the battlefield through magic. It's entirely up to you.

reviewText:
Dominions 4 is a grand strategic game where you play as the god of one of the 77 nations available (spread out over three eras: Early, where magic is plentiful, technology is not, and giants (as well other magical beings) are common; Middle, the time of iron; and Late, time of steel and the ascendance of man.)

Each nation is fully fleshed out, based off of different myths, and has their own strengths, weaknesses, and quirks.

Gameplay is turn-based, with each turn representing one month. You queue up your orders (such as building troops, casting spells, moving, attacking, searching for magic sites, etc.) and, when you've got everything to your liking, you end the turn. Combat takes place simultaneously between turns. Armies are broken into individual soldiers, who are placed into squads. Each general has a command limit of how many men he can lead, and how many squads those can be broken into (although you can make more, at a hit to morale for all the troops under that general) and each squad can be given a formation and basic orders - such as attack closest" or "fire at archers and keep distance". Your generals themselves can be given a list of 5 commands as well as an overall tactic - this is best used for mages

reviewText: Dom4 is basically the same system as Dom3 with some mechanical changes that you probably won't care about unless you have played both games a fair amount and some interface upgrades. The interface improvements do matter, and help to cut down the micromanagement inherent in the game, but there is still a fair amount of turn to turn management that you need to engage in which would be nice to automate. Perhaps the biggest thing to be aware of in this game is that singleplayer is very lacking. The game has a huge amount of depth, thousands of units, hundreds of items and spells; all of which the AI is unable to effectively employ. So if you get this game and intend to play any significant amount, look to get involved with multiplayer. Those are the game's primary flaws, for everything else Dominions delivers nicely. Each of the different nations plays differently from it's peers, and most have sereveral viable paths to pursue as the game developes. The game escalates from small numbers of spearmen fighting eachother to angels and dead gods slugging it out in a world where the sun has been snuffed out by magic. If you can look past the game's quirks, this is a fantastic product with amazing scope and detail. It's well worth your money.

reviewText: Dominions is a pretty good strategy game with lots of variety and depth.  I started with Dominions 3, and now I've jumped in to 4.  I do notice some changes and some definite improvements including a bit more assistance with the micro managing.  It does show as an independent game, of course - the graphics and the manual leave plenty of room for improvement.  But it's hard to beat the variety and depth, and I don't think it's too hard to learn.\nWith the variety of maps, of win conditions, the three eras, the variety of nations, and the variety of gods, there's a lot of ability to customize how you play and cater to your preferences.\nSo far I've only played single player.  The AI does seem reasonably good, plenty of challenge there.  I can only imagine that being able to set up a multi-player game would be quite a lot of fun.

A low graphic, yet good strategy game, following the motif of Master of Magic. Basically you choose a 'nation' to control, build a wanna-be-god for them and set to strategy against other nations where new gods are rising as the old overgod is ... gone. You can equip your leaders/special units with mystical items and there is lots of overland spells and ordinary ones. Not all countries rely on magic. Very diverse game with good replayability factor.

Music score is a little unusual medevil reporductions, though not bad at all. Wish there were a little bit more music themes.

Developer is quite often patching and rebalancing the game, adding more things. Nations, summonable creatures and such at his own pace, but regularely and probably like with his earlier games on a constant basis for years. Pace is slow, but constant. Game is stable, updates are just extra bonus in general.

reviewText: Never before have I played a game that I can describe as beautiful in such an eclectic sense. The town looks absolutely stunning on the PC. The story is rich and provoking, keeping you guessing and revising your theories as you play. The final scenes will haunt you, driving you (or at least many) to the forums to absorb and discuss thoughts on the plot possibilities. The music is captivating and enthralling, with all of its drama. With extra orchestral stabs to accent details such as how you finish an enemy, the experience really feels complete and integrated. The gameplay is familiar for fans of the previous Illwinter games, with new innovations to spice things up. Zipping around the town and dealing out devastating blows is both effective and immensely satisfying. No game is perfect, as no form of entertainment/art is immune to subjectivity but this game comes so close that it deserves a 10/10 for being worth every single coin spent on it.

reviewText: Dominions 4 is an in-depth, involved, immersive game that harkens back to the good old days of turn-based fantasy empire gaming. Tasked with taking the place of the now absent creator of the universe, your character (known as a Pretender God) seeks to become the new, true God. You must build armies, research a huge range of spells, and vanquish rival Pretenders to claim the ultimate prize in creation.\nI really, really like this game. It gives me a warm fuzzy feeling of nostalgia with the graphics, sound effects and just how much depth and substance is here. There's no glitz and dazzle with funky graphics to glamour you. Their are hundreds of spells in several different schools (such as Air, Earth, Fire, Water and darker paths like Death and Blood magic) which can be researched and used to advance your claim to Godhood. Your character can be anything from a wizened old crone, to a titan of the underworld, to a dragon, cyclops, divinely-created bull and many, many more things. This game is worth the price-tag, once you have this you don't need any other strategy games anymore, because this one has enough content to keep you going for a long time. It has a steep learning curve, so be prepared for that, but all the best games are the ones that take a while to get the hang of. Highly recommended to anyone who loves in-depth, fantasy turn-based strategy games.\nI give it 9.6 out of 10.

reviewText:
NOTE: There will be no TL;DR version of this review. To quote Maxi’s review “If you really usually jump for TLDRs don't bother getting the game.”

I want to be clear about this, I love this game. I think it's great fun. I've sunk around 100 hours into Dominions 3, with another 70 into Dom 4. I think Dom 4 is a flat out improvement from its predecessor, and given the choice I would chose to play Dom 4 every time. That said this is not really a game that I could recommend to my friends, let alone to some stranger on the Internet. To start off the graphics are old fashioned and I know a LOT of people who will turn up their nose at a game just because it doesn't look pretty. If the idea of some simple sprites moving across a painted background isn't your idea of an acceptable battle animation then turn around and walk the other way.

The combat may also be something that turns people off. The combat works through a scripting element, something that was designed in part so that players could engage in multiplayer through a play by email style (if that doesn't show you that the game might have some antiquated design ideas hanging around, I don't know what will). This means that you as a player cannot engage in combat in real time, it happens between game turns and you receive a summary and video of what happened in the combat while you were away. You set up your units, tell them where to go and what to do (within certain limitations of course. You cannot, for instance, order your archers to stop firing if friendlies come into danger of being shot, nor can you order your troops to wait more or less than two turns before charging headlong into the enemy), and then they handle everything by themselves without any more input by you. This can sometimes make you feel as though you are being cheated, like if you didn't get a very good scout report and the enemy wound up having cavalry you weren’t prepared for that decimate your troops with their lances. Maybe if you could alter orders on the fly, you would have ordered your mages to cast a spell to stop or slow the cavalry instead of trying to buff your own troops. I find this to just be part of the game, and I enjoy the strategic fetters it places upon my gameplay. Some people, though, may not. This, I think, is the main point of contention one will have with the game. If you can find yourself enjoying the combat, then you'll probably be fine. That said, there are a smattering of more tedious issues that can still turn you away.

One such issue is micromanagement. On a small map with one to four other nations, you can manage your little empire without too much of a struggle. If you try to play on a large map with 12+ nations, you'll be working through a micromanagement slog the likes of which you may have not even comprehended before. If you are playing as a nation with heavy troops capable of only moving one province per turn, may the Pantokrator help you. Add in the fact that the UI is not great, and you might not even know how to do the thing that you want to do. I love micro (I play vanilla Dwarf Fortress as well), and I don't mind referring to the manual when I forget how to do a little thing like copy orders or make a mage cast the same spell every month, but if you aren't willing to find those little time saving things the micro can weigh you down even more quickly.

The last detractor is the AI, and this is the only real reason I'll ever take a break from the game. Dominions is the kind of game that was always developed with multiplayer in mind, and I think that the game gives players a lot of tools to build, execute, and adapt to different strategies. While I haven't played any multiplayer in my time with the game, I have seen several games and read a lot of the theorycrafting involved. While that isn't the same as playing a MP game, I think it gives me a measure of insight into how the game can function differently in MP as opposed to SP. Sadly, the AI isn't very good at using a lot of those strategic tools designed for human players. For example, let's say you have two kinds of units that can hold the line" and buy time for either your ranged units or mages to kill the enemy. The first are heavily armored pikemen capable of repelling

reviewText: A very innovative strategy game with a wide variety of interesting factions. It has an detailed and diverse lore based on various real mythologies and cultures. Battles take place in real time, and manage to apply an old school rpg feel (isometric 2d sprites rolling dice at eachother) to a concept of large scale battles. The number of factions, units, magic spells, and the customization of your god means there are almost limitless strategic possibilities.\n\nThis game probably gets lower numeric review scores because dominions 4 isn't much different from dominions 3, which isn't much different than dominions 2. I agree with this criticism, so if you own Dominions 3 the pricetag is not worth the upgrade. For anyone else interested in mythology and TBS wargames, a very unique and fun experience.

reviewText: Dominions 4 is just one of those games that sure, it doesn't have the amazing graphics of say Civilization or Europa Universalis but it makes up for that with a lot of depth, a ton of content and great replayability. The plotline for the game is fairly basic; Essentially each player is a godlike being called a Pretender, each controls a loyal nation and is battling to become the Pantokrator, or supreme god. To do this a pretender can either do it one of three ways; The first way is to conquer your enemies with vast armies which can take a long time depending on some of the maps, spreading your religion to the point it extinguishes the power of your rivals religion or the new victory condition for this installment, capturing the required number of Thrones of Ascension. Each throne grants you a special perk so to speak and also adds strategy to what provinces you conquer and when. Each nation exists in either one of three ages, sometimes all three. The sheer amount of units in this game is astounded and every single nation in the game is based on history, mythology or fantasy tropes (Although there are no stereotypical Elves or Dwarves at all really.) One of the best parts of the game is also the manual which not only contains information on how to play the game, but it also contains little bits of lore, developer commentary on the different nations and an entire roster of every unit in the game. It is even updated to consider in updates and patches. There is too much content for me to state in this review but the last thing I will say is this; If you enjoy turn based strategy games that give you that One More Turn" mentality and you can look past the dated graphics then this game is well worth the $35 asking price."

reviewText: While this game does have a very steep learning curve, it's definitely worth learning. The gameplay is solid, and I enjoy the graphics and music, but it's really the mechanics that fascinate me most with this game. There's so much depth and customization, and you can even find a modding manual on illwinter's website. That means you can customize the pretender god you play, the nation worshipping said god, the individual units recruited by that nation, and even the weapons and armor available to individual units. It's quite literally staggering. The price looks somewhat steep, but considering it's an indie game with a very small staff, I can sympathize. Try it out, chances are you'll find more than a few things you like.\n\nOne more thing I can say is that if you're still doubtful because of the price tag, go ahead and try playing the Dominions 3 demo first. You can find it at Illwinter's website, and rest assured that dominions 4 is somehow even better than its predecessor, so if you enjoy dom3, then dom4 will be great.

reviewText:
It's like HoMM with more game mechanics. Turn based strategy on large maps that involve dozens to hundreds of units in a single army.
Combat is automated, but setting formations and outfiting commanders with gear is a big aspect of gameplay, as is researching magical spells.
There is no diplomacy in singleplayer. You cannot form alliances and game modes generally encourage total conquest.
The setting is mix of mythology, high fantasy, and historical fiction playable races range from semi-historical cultures such as Authurian Brits, Bureaucratical Chinese, Bloodthirsty Aztecs, and Steel Worshiping Swiss to more fantasy races such as Lava Men, Cave People, Lovecraftian Ocean Dwellers, and Undead Theocracies.

Unfortunately micromanagement becomes a nightmare when you have tons of generals since there's no order queuing. The game has a ton of hotkeys and you'll have to read the 275 page manual to find them all.

The funnest way to play, in my opinion, is to play on a huge map with a ton of races. Everyone will carve little enclaves and you won't have to worry about overwhelmed mid-game because everyone is fighting 3-5 sided wars.

reviewText:
Dominions 4 can be primarily enjoyed in two separate ways.

The first is the single-player experience. I say experience, because the gameplay aspect can be lacking compared to other games that are primarily meant to be played single-player(script based combat, turns being resolved all in one go, no interaction with the AI. Stuff that has to be the way it is because it wouldn't work in a 3 month multiplayer game otherwise)
So why would you play Dominions 4 in single player? For the incredible amount of background lore, or fluff, the game has to offer. There are three separate Eras, each of which has it's own nations(29 for the Early era, 29 for Middle, 23 for Late Era). Now, the beauty of the nations is that each has a very detailed history, which is usually interlinked to other nations both within the era and outside the era.

For instance, the nation of Man(boring name, I know) comes to existance in the Middle Era. It's a nation of knights and witches that live deep in the woods. Quite basic stuff, but they are based on several nations from the Early era. In the Early era, there existed the nation of Marverni, a gallic tribal nation that spread out to the faery land of Tir'na'nog. The fae were driven out, and their magic was stolen by those who would become the witches of Man. The magic of these witches is very similar to that of the fae, but also has aspects of a nearby nation of sea giants that has since gone extinct(In gameplay terms, they share national spells and magic paths). With the fae magic, the witches created a holy order of wardens to protect themselves. During the Late Era, many drastic changes have happened. Magic has fled the lands of Man, and the witches have been replaced by a more secular class of mage-judges, who are some of the only ones that can work magic in the mystically drained land. The wardens of old have lost much of the power the witches had imbued them with, and have had to adapt their tactics in the changing world, turning to the use of crossbows from their old melee-only ways. Most of the nations change in a similar way to this, some die out completely with only remnants of their former nation diffused to other nations, and some new nations arise from nothingness, perhaps containing a smattering of elements from the Early Era, despite showing up in the Late Era.

On the other hand, there's the multiplayer. Where the gameplay was lacking in singleplayer, it's the opposite in multiplayer. It is incredibly deep and satisfying. With so many different nations and hundreds of spells(most of which have a purpose in the game. Though a handful are more or less useless, I think), the different possibilities are quite insane. Perhaps your army is composed of only flying troops, meaning you can fly around the world, striking where the enemy can't defend itself? Perhaps you have spells that can kill enemy commanders, which prevents them from flying around with their armies? Perhaps you have cast a spell of global repercussions which causes the world to be plunged to darkness, where the gold income of every place in the world plummets, unrest increases and battles are fought in pitch black darkness.(quite useful if you use a large amount of undead or you are a cave-dwelling troglodyte). Are your own national troops weak and useless? Well, you can make them more powerful with spells enchanting their strength, or perhaps giving all of them flight during battles, flaming arrows or turning them to mist. Suppose you wanted to summon creatures of legend such as manticores? Perhaps a dead hero you had was dear to you, well you can bring him back as a mummy that causes diseases to anyone nearby! Some may find it useful to craft an artifact sword that causes the temperature on the battlefield to raise, spontaneously combusting troops and causing them to tire out very quickly.  Does your nation lack archers? Why not craft magical bows that shoot a dozen arrows per shot and give a few of them to your commanders, instant ranged ability.

Just keep in mind, Dominions 4 is designed to be played as a slow paced multiplayer game, where you play a turn every few days, so a multiplayer game may last several months. Of course, a singleplayer game is much faster, but since the enemy lacks human ingeniuity, it's far less exciting to play against.

reviewText:
At first glance Dominions 4 can look overwhelming but after time you discover a complex and incredibly deep game with more replayability than any other game out there. If you enjoy building up a civilization and conquering your enimies this game has it all for you. With non interactive combat this game may not appeal to those who enjoy RTS games, with the key to winning very much in the planning of a fight, do i have the right troops? the right spells? (there are so many) have i given the correct orders? these are just some of the things you need to consider prior to fighting. As you play more, you realise that a very important part to your victory is the decision around how you create your race, the pretender design and the magic paths are incredibly important.
This game has so much depth and challenge that it should keep you playing for years.
Playing against other players is hard but challenging and insanely fun, with in and out of game diplomacy allowing you to create alliances or trick others into attacking one another, so much is possible. This is one of those games that doesn't appeal to people after a gorgeous graphical experience but it rewards those who love in depth games that require thought and tactics to get things done.
Amazing.

reviewText:
Loving the game so far, though whilst learning something new every attempt, I still have a loooong way to go before I surpass even the 'utter newbie' stage.

This is the first Dominions game I've played and, I'll be honest, I was put off.  Not by the graphics, they are terrible, but there's a certain charm to them, helped by the music...  But no, it was by the simple fact that you are dumped into the game with no tutorial (there IS a tutorial, but it requires you to read a manual which you either need to print off or buy from the dev's for another £7-8).  The details are not within the tutorial as you may expect.

But, I persevered and watched various videos online to learn more and eventually got myself to finally do the written tutorial which was immensely helpful.

So whilst I recommend the game, I would also advise it is not for someone who just expects to jump right in and play it.  I had to watch videos just to learn how to use the interface, let alone actually play the game.  So be prepared to have to do a little work to actually begin enjoying it.

Once you get through this though, there is a fantastic amount of depth to it.  Plus, as a huge bonus, you get to play as R'yleh...  As a massive Lovecraft fan, this is always a bonus :).

If you must play one strategy game in 2014, make it Dominions.

Dominions 4 is an amazing game with alot of depth, don't let the simple graphics and rather obtuse UI tell you otherwise. There are hundreds of units, hundreds of spells and thousands of strategies to use to become the ultimate god. Every nation is different, from the Dominion of Ermor which kills the populace within it's domain in order to fuel it's undead armies, the fire children Abysians which are wreathed in flame and burn their way through their enemies.

reviewText: I highly recommend this game to any strategy enthusiasts, or fans of mythology, out there. I'll go ahead and get the (tiny) amount of criticism out of the way - the game has an unusual user interface, and targeted selection of units can be especially tedious at times. With that detail out of the way, I only have good things to say about Dominions 3. The writing in the game is top-notch, and very immersive. You often have to play multiple races to get a fuller picture of the history, but it's rich and satisfying once you piece it together. The Tuatha and the Fomorian Giants are a good example. The game plays in a traditional fashion concerning territories and the movement of agents and armies, much like other turn-based games. However, to locate the useful goodies in a territory, you'll have to cultivate a few powerful mages among your commanders, to find hidden sites that can provide mana gems, unique and powerful units for recruitment, or special effects, once unearthed. You'll need them (and magi once again) for the forging of magical items to equip your agents, priests, mages, generals, prophet, and your Pretender God. But the true meat of the game is in spreading your dominion (aka faith) across the map. It is the source of your power, and since it can flow into enemy territoy, it can also hamper their efforts to withstand your (inevitable) attack. Be sure to build lots of temples in your own honor! Put those puny mortal mages to work researching powerful magic that can affect the whole world. Turn day to perpetual night, bring on and endless winter, summon hurricanes, kill someone from anywhere in the world, dispach the flying monkeys to pluck away some unfortunate soul! Last Pretender God standing wins the prize - true Godhood. Sounds simple, right? Think again. It's a deep and complex game, and can be quite the challenge at times. So join in the fun, weave your own epic tale! Smash vampires with giants, ♥♥♥♥♥ queens (yes, its a real Pretender) with a midget masher, or run from Cthulu! It's all in there, and waiting for you! Order now!

This game is very hard and not for the weak of heart, the gameplay is the result of a decade of perfectionment and it shows: there is simply a huge lot of ways to solve your problem: units, spells, artefacts, diplomacy ... you literaly feel like a god.

However having some help for combats would be a plus, it is really hard as is to see if your army is strong against your opponent's without a lot of experience of all spells, objects and units involved; which can bring you to sacrifice powerful units on your opponent because you did not know that his units are virtually invicible to yours. Having a detailled combat report (which spell/units killed which unit, how much gems have been consumed and by who, how much damage have been spared by the units armors...) could also help a lot for beginners like me ! Even being able to rewind the combats to assess by hand the damages and deaths could be of help.

Also too bad the graphics are so cryptics and ugly, especially the UI and map overlays, it does not help with the difficulty when you cannot assess  at a quick glance the state of your dominion. Having a strategic map that looks more polished would probably make this game more enjoyable and while it would mean some work, it would not necessitate a 3D rework of any kind, just look at Heroes 2/3 for an example of 2D strategic UI that is beautiful, informative and easy to understand. Some ugliness lies also in the anti-aliasing abuse on every element, I understand it is probably to give more homogeneity to the sprites but it seems like a cheap trick.

It seems like a negative review but I swear it is not: this game is awesome, buy it if you haven't already, I just have to spare the rod and spoil the child ;)

reviewText:
Poor graphics, very limited animations, can't load previous save if you do something poorly.

Correction: Beautiful art, pleasant backgrounds, gameplay that encourages responsibility and risks.
Plenty of depht, something sorely lacking in most games. I played Dom 3 for years and I kept finding new things I had never figured. Who knew there was a secret kingdom of mirror-assassins all along? Well look at that, an oak in my capital now gives me gems. Oh cool, I made a demon castle in three red seconds.

This game is the most awesome strategy game there is, just like Dominions 3 was. The changes are not many but all of them have made it better. The new province-history screens give yet even more chance for RP, you can count the kills on your commanders, the individual age of each of your troops (hint: play pangea and they all live VEEERY long), and be a smart general by giving orders to your guys before the actual combat. I am yet to try the team-mode but from the little tinkering I have tried, it looks pretty good. Will put limitations on prophets though.

But there are a few downsides that have been around bothering me sometimes. I will introduce them, as well.
Diplomacy is sadly not present. Looking at the lore of the game, it shouldn't be, you are fighting against rival pretender gods after all.
Luckily multiplayer can fix it... if you trust the players more than the AI. Just remember to bargain monthly tributes of gold and gems, and go raiding their provinces if they wont pay ;)


All in all. Buy this game. If you think you could give it a try, do it. If you are willing to try learn and dive in, you can do it!

reviewText:
I have played Dominions since the original, and have always enjoyed it.  It is one of my favorites, and I come back to it every few months.  Each version has brought improvements, and 4 is the best so far.  I don't mind spending the money for the new versions, because supporting a durable indy developer is priceless.

There are numerous races to be played, and they are all very different.  There is a ton of replay value, just trying out new factions and learning their strengths and weaknesses.  It also makes you a better player, since those factions appear in other playthroughs as your rivals, and there is nothing like knowing your enemies intimately.

This very diversity of strategies leads to the game's major limitation: the AI opponent presents a very weak challenge.  It simply isn't built to compete at your level, so you will get to the point where playing against the computer is like playing against a young child: the only way to create a challenge is to let it cheat gratuitously.  Higher difficulty levels simply give the AI more and more bonuses, rather than kicking in more cleverness or sophistication.  I recognize that game AI is still a fantasy, but this is a fantasy game after all. ;)

I am confident that human players would provide that competition; however, I have never had the flexibility to commit to that kind of long social engagement.  I will continue to dream of a day when the computer opponent is as satisfying as a person.

reviewText:
This is a deep turn-based strategy title that's about spreading you your deity’s religious power through conquest and proselytizing. It’s a fantasy title and has something like 10,000+ unique spells between the different factions.

Your deity’s avatar (pretender god) will appear at some point, which you preset. You pick the time period you want to start the game in, which will affect technology and available starting factions. You need a pretty hefty system to run it at max fps, there’s a lot of calculations that go on in the background. The graphics aren’t spectacular either way. Combat is hands off. You set the tactics and formations your commanders will use, as well as the dispositions of the units. Spying will help you know how to set your tactics. Proselytizing will give you advantages as the faith of the locals will change advantages. Watching post-combat reports and fact sheets will be hugely beneficial on how you change your tactics for the next conflict with that particular army. As you learn the game it becomes even deeper. The dev’s made it so it’s easy to make your own maps, and the community has uploaded quite a few between Dominions 3-4. The game does allow you to build up territories that you control. You can also search for places of power, which give you advantages. Research will allow you to have access to more powerful spells (and better craftables), which allow you to more fully utilize the power of your casters (individual units have caps on capabilities and with what kinds of spells they can utilize; it’s all part of the strategy).

I’ve enjoyed this title, and if you like strategy games this is a title you will like. It’s from a small dev team, which has a long heritage of solid strategy/tactical games. If you buy it from the dev’s website (or their publisher) you will get the DRM-free version as well as a steam key. Desura was also giving you a key if you had a license from the dev (I’m not sure if they still do or if Desura is a healthy company at this point).

reviewText:
This is a deep turn-based strategy title that's about spreading you your deity’s religious power through conquest and proselytizing. It’s a fantasy title and has something like 10,000+ unique spells between the different factions.

Your deity’s avatar (pretender god) will appear at some point, which you preset. You pick the time period you want to start the game in, which will affect technology and available starting factions. You need a pretty hefty system to run it at max fps, there’s a lot of calculations that go on in the background. The graphics aren’t spectacular either way. Combat is hands off. You set the tactics and formations your commanders will use, as well as the dispositions of the units. Spying will help you know how to set your tactics. Proselytizing will give you advantages as the faith of the locals will change advantages. Watching post-combat reports and fact sheets will be hugely beneficial on how you change your tactics for the next conflict with that particular army. As you learn the game it becomes even deeper. The dev’s made it so it’s easy to make your own maps, and the community has uploaded quite a few between Dominions 3-4. The game does allow you to build up territories that you control. You can also search for places of power, which give you advantages. Research will allow you to have access to more powerful spells (and better craftables), which allow you to more fully utilize the power of your casters (individual units have caps on capabilities and with what kinds of spells they can utilize; it’s all part of the strategy).

I’ve enjoyed this title, and if you like strategy games this is a title you will like. It’s from a small dev team, which has a long heritage of solid strategy/tactical games. If you buy it from the dev’s website (or their publisher) you will get the DRM-free version as well as a steam key. Desura was also giving you a key if you had a license from the dev (I’m not sure if they still do or if Desura is a healthy company at this point).

reviewText:
This is one of the best strategy game I have ever played. Dominions 4 is a fantasy 4x game, heavily focused on warfare and magic development... and a very distinctive God-building system (yes, you are the God of your civilization).

In order to achieve your goal (rule over the world destroying your enemies, making of your God faith the only one remaining or claiming several magical sites) you will need more than controlling land and building your armies... You will have to take advantage of your nation strenghts and sinergies, take control of territories with strategic resources and special troops available, and craft special equipment for your commanders, as well as develop your magical level. You can also know what is wrong with your armies as you may actually see the battles you are involved in, knowing this way how your troops are performing, among them and against your enemies.

This game has an incredible amount of nations, units, spells, enchantments, equipment... available, which is a guarantee of replayability. Content that is constantly increased by free patches.

Though graphics and interface look a bit outdated, this is a very immersive game, with lots of possibilities, and an important community modding it and with lots of multiplayer games active. Highly recommendable.

reviewText:
I find Dominions 4 to be fascinatingly intricate and polished, a credible result for 10+ years of dedicated evolution over four sequels, from what I've gathered. I've seen that in series before, yet somehow I'm still impressed here. Right after I got it, I told a friend of mine who spent about a year of his free time playing two humongous maps of Age of Wonders II--something I never expected [was a typo] when I gave it to him as his first brush with the genre--that my initial estimate puts Dominions 4 at about (AoW2)^2 in content. Personally, I relish a steep learning curve: grand strategy titles and deeply dynamic RPG character building systems have been particular pleasures down this line. Nevertheless, starting Dominions 4 I was surprised such as I haven't been in a long time to see I had underestimated how much I wouldn't know.

At first I was moderately impressed at the apparent scope of the thing, and I started to get burnt out on my course of study about the time I felt I could look at the nations lists with their dozens of choices and think I could describe the basic flavor for all of them. But then for the first time I looked at my first details about the magical and crafting systems and as ideas and dimensions began to click I was truly impressed like I had finally shifted the top layer of this giant package, and underneath it was still layers more good and integrated stuff!

The more I've dug up hour after hour of yet more complimentary game dynamics and worldbuilding flavor, the more I've thought I wish I had bought this game full price instead of on sale: all the more power to the developers if they're this kind of craftsmen.

reviewText:
I discovered Dominions when it was Dom2.  That game was very hard to understand and play.  Dom3 was much, much better and Dom4 (in my opinion) is a modest improvement.  There is a lot to like about this game: building your god (I really like that part), discovering and using magic, and researching some of the over 800 spells.  Not to mention several dozen different nations to play with and each of those in THREE ages (i.e. different ages of the world).  I don't think it's possible to play the same game twice the same way; there's just too much diversity.

It's easy to take this game as a series of battles: win every battle, beat the other god(s) and you win the game.  Wrong!  It is about magic and if you don't utilize magic, you will lose.  That alone makes it a challenging game to understand and play, and win.  I really like that part of the game.

But here's the problem for me:  It is a massively detailed micro-manager game.  You have to check every thing in every  province, every turn, and usually every army (or part of an army) every turn, and anything and everything else in every part of the game and almost every part of the map -- every turn!  If you really, really like that in a game, this is one you must buy.  It is fun, and interesting, and deep and complex...but after a while I find it overwhelmingly tedious.
